item.title: Betting on Virtual Reality
item.dc:creator: josephscott
item.description: Greg Linden is betting against mass adoption of VR: So, Daniel and I have another bet: “Virtual reality hardware (not counting cardboard) will not sell more than 10M units/year worldwide before March 2019.” I’m saying it won’t. Daniel says it will. Loser donates $100 to the winner’s choice of charity. I’m with Greg on this […]
item.content:encoded:
Greg Linden is betting against mass adoption of VR:

So, Daniel and I have another bet: “Virtual reality hardware (not counting cardboard) will not sell more than 10M units/year worldwide before March 2019.” I’m saying it won’t. Daniel says it will. Loser donates $100 to the winner’s choice of charity.

I’m with Greg on this one. There are plenty of interesting individual applications for VR, but their numbers will be small and specialized. At least for the next few years.

item.title: Solar Panel Offsets
item.dc:creator: josephscott
item.description: Greg Linden is looking for a broader solar panel market: Why can’t I buy a solar panel and enjoy the electricity credit from that solar panel when it is installed in a nice sunny spot in the Southwest? Phoenix, Arizona has about twice the solar energy efficiency of Seattle. Why can’t I buy a solar […]
item.content:encoded:
Greg Linden is looking for a broader solar panel market:

Why can’t I buy a solar panel and enjoy the electricity credit from that solar panel when it is installed in a nice sunny spot in the Southwest?

Phoenix, Arizona has about twice the solar energy efficiency of Seattle. Why can’t I buy a solar panel and enjoy the electricity credit from that solar panel when it is installed in a nice sunny spot in the Southwest?

This feels like a potential market waiting to be explored. I suspect there is a mountain of legal and regulatory paperwork that would need to be ascended before it could be done on a large scale ( the entire United States for instance ).
